titlestmt.titleproper: Rockefeller Brothers Fund records, Awards in Arts Education Program, RG 7
A Guide to the Rockefeller Brothers Fund records, Awards in Arts Education Program, RG 7 FA776

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-03-13 16:46:31 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.unittitle: Rockefeller Brothers Fund records, Awards in Arts Education Program, RG 7

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: In 1980, the trustees of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund approved the establishment of a five-year program of Awards in Arts Education to identify and encourage exemplary arts programs in public elementary and secondary schools. In a departure from usual policy, the RBF directed the program itself rather than making a grant for that purpose to an outside organization. Between 1982 and 1985, a total of 33 schools received awards of $10,000 each. Awards went to schools whose arts programs were marked by high quality and significant achievement, as judged by the Fund and its 12-member Arts Award Committee. The Award Committee reviewed 1,200 applications, making site visits to 104 finalist schools in 37 states in the first four years of the program.

Three years into the program, however, the members of the Award Committee and the Fund staff involved came to recognize that in most instances, although the awards recognized schools, the excellence that the Fund discovered and rewarded was the result of outstanding teachers or groups of teachers, not programs or curricula that were excellent in the abstract. The RBF invited a group of these outstanding teachers to participate in "A Seminar of Exploration", a five-day research seminar focused not on the teaching of art, but on the art of teaching, and designed to help the Fund better understand how these teachers succeeded in building outstanding programs within the public schools. The Seminar was held in August 1984 at Endicott House Conference Center in Dedham, Massachusetts.

By the fifth year and final year of the program, the RBF found that the quality of applications to the Awards program had declined. David Rockefeller, Jr., RBF trustee and chairman of the Arts Award Committee, said that the judging committee noted, among the general factors contributing to this decline in quality, the "loss of strong incentives for arts improvement that followed the elimination of federal programs designed to enhance curriculum balance; and the appearance of new requirements that limit schools' flexibility to pursue quality in the arts through innovation and enlightened improvisation." Rather than conducting a competition in year five (1986), the Fund chose instead to pursue the most promising opportunities to share available knowledge and insights from top arts programs, including Award winners as well as a number of the runner-up schools.

"A Report on the RBF Awards in Arts Education Program", dated July 1989 – a draft copy of which appears in these files – is a rich resource detailing the RBF's Awards in Arts Education Program. It includes an in-depth look at each of the 33 award schools, including how each school spent their award money and post-award developments within each school. Also included are essays on six of the award schools, written by poets and journalists commissioned by the RBF.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The material in this record group primarily covers the period from 1981-1985, when the Awards in Arts Education Program was actively distributing cash awards. Earliest dated material, however dates from 1973 and latest is from 1989.
Each of the three series offers a distinctive view of the Awards in Arts Education Program.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The material in this collection is divided into three series: Award Winners, Administration, and Applications. These three series are further divided into subseries, primarily by award year. This arrangement reflects the original order in which the material was received.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Standard processing was conducted by Gail Antos, 2016. All records have been placed in acid free lignin free folders and rehoused in archival manuscript boxes. Original folder titles have been primarily maintained.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. Researchers are asked to check the "Restrictions" note for each Title. If a Title does not currently have an access copy, please contact a RAC archivist for further instruction.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Rockefeller Archive Center has title to the collection and has authority to grant permission to cite and publish archival material from the collection. Rockefeller Brothers Fund retains copyright and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series 1, Award Winners, contains detailed information about each of the 33 winning schools. Each school's file is divided into several sections, including Grant Payment Letter-Narrative/Expenditure Reports, School Application, Committee Comments, Publicity, Miscellaneous, and Essay. In addition, most award schools submitted extensive supplementary material to demonstrate their arts programs which is included in this series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series 3, Applications, is the largest of the three series and demonstrates the popularity of the Awards program based on the sheer number of applications received.
